questions.question: The narrator suggests that Mathilde’s problem is that she:

choices.answer: needs more servants to help in the house
was born into the wrong social class
does not know how to manage what she has
does not really love her husband

questions.question: In order to get the money to replace the necklace, the Loisels

choices.answer: borrow from the bank, a jeweler, and a loan shark,
ask Mme. F and the jeweler to let them pay the debt slowly
borrow, work hard, take on extra jobs, move...
borrow, but do not reduce their standard of living.
attends the big party
gets the party invitation
replaces the necklace
finally pays off her debt

questions.question: Mme. Forestier responds to Mathilde’s final revelation with

choices.answer: cruel mockery
compassion and generosity
Horror
Amazement

questions.question: At the end of the story, it is plain that

choices.answer: the Loisels will soon become wealthy
the Loisels have learned an important lesson about thrifting
the Loisels have suffered needlessly
Mme. Forestier will help the Loisels

questions.question: If you were summarizing “The Necklace,” you would mention

choices.answer: a grand scheme
a necklace made of fake diamonds
a couple who had been happy and well off
two women who had an enduring friendship

questions.question: Among the following, the best example of irony is that

choices.answer: Mathilde is a charming woman with great ambitions
Mathilde walks on the Champs Élysées to relax
Mathildes success at the ball leads to the ruin of her dream
Mathilde decides to borrow a necklace to go to a party
there's a conflict between expected and what happens
a character says one thing but means another
a character does not know what is going to happen to him/her
the reader but not the character knows whats going to happen

questions.question: What motivated Mme. Forestier to loan the necklace to Mathilde?

choices.answer: Mme. Forestier did not particularly like the necklace.
Mme. Forestier had a lot of necklaces and wouldn't miss one.
Mme. Forestier wanted to be nice to a childhood friend.
Mme. Forestier could not go to the party herself.

questions.question: What is the likely cause of Mme Forestiers failure to recognize Mathilde on the Champs Élysées?

choices.answer: Mme. Forestier was preoccupied with her own child.
Mathilde’s appearance had changed drastically in ten years.
Mathilde was wearing old clothes and had not fixed her hair.
Mme. F didn't know about the replacement of the necklace.

choices.answer: a difficult divorce
his parents splitting at a young age
a war
